div.sent: Is the population increasing?
In order to find the answer, one has to look at population statistics, which requires some searching.
These two figures show that in the 10 years between 1991 and 2001 the population of Bangladesh has increased by 1.78 crore.
According to the 2001 census report the annual population growth rate is 1.48 percent.2
Based on these, it can be predicted that in 2010 the population will be 15 crore.
Students have already learned in the earlier classes about the problems created by rapid increase in population.
Rapid increase in population brings in its wake several problems.
Individuals and government are under great pressure to provide the basic necessities of food, clothe, shelter, treatment, andeducation for the increasing population.
Again, providing employment for the huge workforce is also a major problem.
To fulfil these basic needs require economic solvency and resource.
There are some other issues that arise due to population increase.
There being not much employment for the rural people, many are migrating to cities, or urban areas.
This is leading to the cropping up of unplanned and unhygienic slums in the cities.
It is not possible to provide even the minimum of healthful living conditions.
The first and the most basic necessity for the people is food.
Now, the question is how to meet the food requirements for the increasing population?
The answer is, by increasing food production.
In that case, the food production has to go on increasing with the increasing population, but to what limits can this go on.
No cultivable land is left fallow in Bangladesh.
There is no possibility of getting more cultivable land.
The amount of forestland necessary for environmental equilibrium is also not enough.
So if more of the forest is cut down, environmental equilibrium will be severely affected.
The population of Bangladesh has increased from 5.52 to 12.9 crore in the last 40 years (1961 2001).
That is, it has more than doubled.
To provide for the double population, the amount of food produced had to be more than doubled too.
What needs to be done to increase food production?
It requires healthy seeds of high- yielding variety, fertiliser, insecticide, herbicide, and supply of plenty of water for the land.
The IRRI (International Rice Research Institute) and BRRI (Bangladesh Rice Research Institute) are two varieties of high-yielding rice.
In addition to fertiliser, plenty of water is needed to cultivate IRRI and BRRI.
What is needed for supply of water is a source and irrigation management.
Rain is a source of water.
Water bodies that hold the rainwater, for example, rivers, canals, lakes, ponds and low land can also be source of water.
Supply of water to the land from these sources is the traditional way.
About 37 percent of the cultivable land are watered from these surface water sources.
Surface water is contaminated by human activities.
On the other hand, IRRI and BRRI can be cultivated throughout the year.
Again, for a good harvest, plenty of water is needed.
This extra water has to be supplied by irrigation.
As the surface water is not sufficient for irrigation, scientists have come up with an alternative'underground water.
Nowadays, the underground water is widely used for irrigation throughout the year and for all sorts of crops.
This method has increased crop production and the food requirement is also being met.
But excess use of underground water is causing some harmful effects too, which is neither visible yet nor can be estimated.
The underground water is extracted by deep tubewells, and the water distributed through channels.
As more and more underground water is extracted by deep tubewells, the groundwater table falls and goes further away from the surface.
From the above discussion it is understood that increased population demands increased food production which requires increased irrigation by water extracted by deep tube-wells.
This leads to decreased water on the surface and subsoil, leading to imbalance in the environment.
To save the people from the impending situation, several measures to control or limit the population needs to be undertaken.
This will not create any new problem, rather will improve the quality of life.
Because of the rapidly increasing population, it is becoming necessary to arrange employment for the able workforce.
How can this be done?
Agriculture is the profession of most people.
About 60 percent of the workforce is involved with agriculture or related activities.
Agriculture can no more provide work to more people, so profession alternative to agriculture has to be thought out.
Other alternatives can be profession related to industrial work, business, and social services.
Besides, opportunities for selfemployment need to be created.
The Government of Bangladesh has paid increased attention to industries to create employment opportunities.
New industries are being set up in different places.
Among the industries are jute, spinning and textile, steel, paper, chemical and medicine, fertiliser, and so on.
For the above mentioned industries, mills and factories, lots of soft water is needed.
Some factories do not need very good quality water, such as tannery, which can use the surface water available anywhere.
Cement factories require lots of water.
For example, to prepare one ton of paper requires 90,920 litres of water.
Again, production of one ton of steel requires 45,500 litres of water.
The water for these industrial activities is extracted from underground.
The increased extraction of water is causing the underground water table to fall.
As a result, less pure drinking water is collected underground and less is available to the people.
These measures have both good and bad aspects.
The good aspect is that the country is gradually achieving self-sufficiency in food production.
The grazing land for cattle is also being brought under cultivation leading to shortage of cattle feed.
The weather is becoming dry, and all these together are causing desertification and environmental imbalance.
The sum of all the people'male, female, child, old, disabled'living in a country is the population of that country.
The sum of all the people living in all the countries of the world is the world population.
Over time, the world population is gradually increasing, currently it has exceeded 6 billion.
Population study as a discipline is known as demography.
Demographic information is important for planning, particularly by governments, in fields such as health, education, housing, social security, employment, and environmental preservation.
Usually natural growth rate is calculated from the crude birth rate and crude death rate.
The crude birth and death rates are calculated for a period of one year.
So the ratio of birth and death to the total population is multiplied by But the natural growth rate is calculated in per 100 population.
So, dividing the difference between crude birth rate and crude death rate by 10 will give the natural growth rate.
The natural growth rate can also be calculated directly from the number of births and deaths instead of from birth and death rates.
Children, widows, and aged couples usually do not influence the increase in population.
But in calculating the birth rate, they are also included in the calculation (denominator), so the calculated birth rate is qualified as crude.
On the other hand, the death rate among different ages is not the same.
Besides birth and death, migration also affects the population increase or decrease.
The natural growth rate is so termed because it does not consider the migration factor, only the births and deaths are taken into consideration.
